page.title: 02THE WIGAN PIER COMPLEX #1
page.content: It used to be considered a joke about Wigan having a{"Pier"}but throughout{ Wigan's industrial history{coal}has always played a very important part. Much of this coal was delivered to Wigan Pier on the{Leeds - Liverpool {Canal.}The term Wigan Pier Complex has been given because of the importance of Wigan Pier over many years. Wigan Pier was one of several canal piers built to serve local collieries. Coal would be transported along a "wagon road" and then onto a railway down to the banks of the canal. From here coal would be taken by barge to {Liverpool}and much of it exported to {Ireland}and the{U.S.A. The Pier was one of the last still working. Built in{1822}by T.Claughton to serve his pits, it was linked to other pits in 1842 and demolished in {1929}for a total scrap value of Â£34.
